questions.question_html:
Which of the following is the right steps to show the work for below:

Why is 3\frac{2}{5} - 1\frac{4}{7} the same as \frac{3}{7} + 1\frac{2}{5}?
questions.question:
Which of the following is the right steps to show the work for below:

Why is `$3\frac{2}{5} - 1\frac{4}{7}$` the same as `$\frac{3}{7} + 1\frac{2}{5}$`?
questions.answer_html:
3\frac{2}{5} - 1\frac{4}{7}

= 3 + \frac{2}{5} -1 -\frac{4}{7}

= 3 -1 + \frac{2}{5} -\frac{4}{7}

= 2 -\frac{4}{7} + \frac{2}{5}

= 1 + 1 -\frac{4}{7} + \frac{2}{5}

= 1 -\frac{4}{7} + 1 + \frac{2}{5}

= \frac{3}{7} + 1 \frac{2}{5}

questions.question_html:
Which of the following is the right steps to show the work for below:

Why is 3\frac{2}{3} - 1\frac{5}{6} the same as 3\frac{5}{6} - 2?
questions.question:
Which of the following is the right steps to show the work for below:

Why is `$3\frac{2}{3} - 1\frac{5}{6}$` the same as `$3\frac{5}{6} - 2$`?
questions.answer_html:
3\frac{2}{3} - 1\frac{5}{6}

=3+ \frac{2}{3} - 1- \frac{5}{6}

=3+ \frac{2}{3} - 1- \frac{5}{6} + +\frac{5}{6} - \frac{5}{6}

=3 +\frac{5}{6}+ \frac{2}{3} - 1- \frac{5}{6} - \frac{5}{6}

=(3 +\frac{5}{6})+ (\frac{2}{3} - 1- \frac{5}{6} - \frac{5}{6})

=(3 +\frac{5}{6})+ (-2)

=3\frac{5}{6}-2

questions.question_html:
(a) Evaluate each power: (-2)^2, (-2)^3, (-2)^4, (-2)^5

(b) Examine the signs of your answers. What pattern do you notice?

(c) Explain how you can tell the sign of the answer when a power has a negative base. Create and use examples of your own to illustrate your explanation.
questions.question:
**(a)** Evaluate each power: `$(-2)^2, (-2)^3, (-2)^4, (-2)^5$`

**(b)** Examine the signs of your answers. What pattern do you notice? 

**(c)** Explain how you can tell the sign of the answer when a power has a negative base. Create and use examples of your own to illustrate your explanation.
questions.answer:
a) 4, -8, 16, -32

b) When the exponent is odd, the power is negative, and
when the exponent is even, the power is positive.

c) Negative bases will give a positive answer if the
exponent is even {`$ (-1)^2 = -1 \times -1 = 1$`} and a negative answer if the exponent is odd 

{`$ (-1)^3 = -1 \times -1 \times -1 = -1$`}
questions.answer_html:
a) 4, -8, 16, -32

b) When the exponent is odd, the power is negative, and when the exponent is even, the power is positive.

c) Negative bases will give a positive answer if the exponent is even { (-1)^2 = -1 \times -1 = 1} and a negative answer if the exponent is odd

{ (-1)^3 = -1 \times -1 \times -1 = -1}

questions.question_html: Assume b and n are positive integers. When n is an odd number, decide whether -b^n +(-b)^n is positive, negative, or zero. Explain your reasoning.
questions.question: Assume `$b$` and `$n$` are positive integers.  When `$n$` is an odd number, decide whether `$-b^n +(-b)^n$` is positive, negative, or zero.   Explain your reasoning.
questions.answer: Negative. If `$n$` is odd, then both `$-b^n$` and `$(-b)^n$` would have negative values. When you add two negative values, the answer would be negative.
questions.answer_html: Negative. If n is odd, then both -b^n and (-b)^n would have negative values. When you add two negative values, the answer would be negative.

questions.question_html: Assume b and n are positive integers. When n is an even number, decide whether -b^n +(-b)^n is positive, negative, or zero. Explain your reasoning.
questions.question: Assume `$b$` and `$n$` are positive integers.  When n is an even number, decide whether `$-b^n +(-b)^n$` is positive, negative, or zero.   Explain your reasoning.
questions.answer: Zero. If `$n$` is even, then `$-b^n$` would be negative and `$(-b)^n$` would be positive. The magnitudes of the numbers would be equal, so the values would be opposites. The sum of two opposite numbers is zero.
questions.answer_html: Zero. If n is even, then -b^n would be negative and (-b)^n would be positive. The magnitudes of the numbers would be equal, so the values would be opposites. The sum of two opposite numbers is zero.

questions.question_html: Which of the following correctly explains 3\frac{1}{5} - 2\frac{1}{4} has the same answer as \frac{3}{4} + \frac{1}{5}?
questions.question: Which of the following correctly explains `$3\frac{1}{5} - 2\frac{1}{4}$` has the same answer as `$\frac{3}{4} + \frac{1}{5}$`?
questions.answer_html:
3\frac{1}{5} - 2\frac{1}{4}

=3+\frac{1}{5} - 2-\frac{1}{4}

=3-2 +\frac{1}{5} -\frac{1}{4}

=1 +\frac{1}{5} -\frac{1}{4}

=\frac{1}{5}+ 1 -\frac{1}{4}

=\frac{1}{5}+ (1 -\frac{1}{4})

=\frac{1}{5}+ \frac{3}{4}

=\frac{3}{4} + \frac{1}{5}

questions.question_html:
Which of the following correctly explains why below is equal or not equal to \displaystyle \frac{3}{4}(\frac{5}{8}).

\displaystyle -\frac{3}{4}(-\frac{5}{8})
questions.question:
Which of the following correctly explains why below is equal or not equal to `$\displaystyle \frac{3}{4}(\frac{5}{8})$`.

`$
\displaystyle
 -\frac{3}{4}(-\frac{5}{8})	
$`
questions.answer_html:
Same because

\displaystyle \frac{-3}{4}(\frac{5}{-8})

= \displaystyle (-\frac{3}{4})(-\frac{5}{8})

= \displaystyle (-1)(-1)(\frac{3}{4})(\frac{5}{8})

= \displaystyle (+1)(\frac{3}{4})(\frac{5}{8})

= \displaystyle (\frac{3}{4})(\frac{5}{8})

questions.question_html:
Which of the following explains the two are either same or not same? -8^2 and (-8)^2.

HINT
questions.question:
Which of the following explains the two are either same or not same?  `$-8^2$` and `$(-8)^2$`.

[HINT](https://youtu.be/_a1WE-oq4yY)
questions.answer_html:
(-8)^2

=(-8)(-8)

=(-1)(8)(-1)(8)

=(-1)(-1)(8)(8)

=(-1)^2(8)^2

=(+1)8^2

\neq -8^2

questions.question_html:
Complete the table to show the relationship between the metric units of length. Express each relationship as a power with base 10.

\displaystyle \begin{array}{|l|l|l|l|l|} \hline & Millimetres & Centimetres & Metres & Kilometres \\ \hline Millimetres & & & & \\ \hline Centimetres & & & & \\ \hline Metres & & & & \\ \hline Kilometres & & & & \\ \hline \end{array}
questions.question:
Complete the table to show the relationship between the metric units of length. Express each relationship as a power with base 10.

`$\displaystyle
\begin{array}{|l|l|l|l|l|}
\hline & Millimetres & Centimetres & Metres & Kilometres \\
\hline Millimetres & & & & \\
\hline Centimetres & & & & \\
\hline Metres & & & & \\
\hline Kilometres & & & & \\
\hline
\end{array}
$`
questions.answer:
`$\displaystyle
\begin{array}{|l|c|c|c|c|}
\hline & Millimetres & Centimetres & Metres & Kilometres \\
\hline Millimetres & &  10^{-1}  &  10^{-3}  &  10^{-6}  \\
\hline Centimetres &  10^{1}  & &  10^{-2}  &  10^{-5}  \\
\hline Metres &  10^{3}  &  10^{2}  & &  10^{-3}  \\
\hline Kilometres &  10^{6}  &  10^{5}  &  10^{3}  & \\
\hline
\end{array}
$`

*mistake in video*
questions.answer_html:
\displaystyle \begin{array}{|l|c|c|c|c|} \hline & Millimetres & Centimetres & Metres & Kilometres \\ \hline Millimetres & & 10^{-1} & 10^{-3} & 10^{-6} \\ \hline Centimetres & 10^{1} & & 10^{-2} & 10^{-5} \\ \hline Metres & 10^{3} & 10^{2} & & 10^{-3} \\ \hline Kilometres & 10^{6} & 10^{5} & 10^{3} & \\ \hline \end{array}

mistake in video

questions.question_html: A pool table is always twice as long as it is wide. The Cue Ball Company makes pool tables in may different sizes. Each table top must have rubber bumpers around the outside edge and a felt top. The rubber bumpers cost $2.25/m and the felt material for the top costs $28/m^2. Determine an algebraic expression that represents the total cost for feet and rubber for the table top. Use this to determine the cost of the materials for a top that has a width of 1.5m.
questions.question:
A pool table is always twice as long as it is wide.   The Cue Ball Company makes pool tables in may  different sizes.  Each table top must have rubber bumpers around the outside edge and a felt top.   The rubber bumpers cost $2.25/m and the felt material for the top costs $`$28/m^2$`.  Determine an algebraic expression that represents the total cost for feet and rubber for the table top.   Use this to determine the cost of the materials for a top that has a width of 1.5m.


#176
questions.answer: The cost is `$28(2x^2)+2.25(6x)$` or `$56x^2+13.5x$`, where `$x$` is the width of the table in metres. When `$x= 1.5$`m, the cost is `$\$146.25$`.
questions.answer_html: The cost is 28(2x^2)+2.25(6x) or 56x^2+13.5x, where x is the width of the table in metres. When x= 1.5m, the cost is \$146.25.

lectures.name: 001. Introduction to setting up Money and time with y=mx+b

questions.question_html:
Jan is a plumber. She charges $35 to visit a job site. Her hourly rate is $43.50. Fred repairs furnaces. He charges $41 for a service call plus $38.75/h. Let x represent the number of hours they work.

  • a) Represent Jan's bill as a polynomial.
  • b) Represent Fred's bill as a polynomial.
  • c) Write a new polynomial that represents Jan's and Fred's combined charge, assuming that they both work x hours at a site.
  • d) Calculate their combined charge i they both work 8 h at the same complex.
questions.question:
Jan is a plumber.  She charges $35 to visit a job site.  Her hourly rate is $43.50.  Fred repairs furnaces.  He charges $41 for a service call plus $38.75/h.  Let `$x$` represent the number of hours they work.

* **a)** Represent Jan's bill as a polynomial.
* **b)** Represent Fred's bill as a polynomial.
* **c)** Write a new polynomial that represents Jan's and Fred's combined charge, assuming that they both work x hours at a site.
* **d)** Calculate their combined charge i they both work 8 h at the same complex.
questions.answer_html:
a) 43.5x +35

b) 38.75x+41

c) 82.25x+76

d) \$734.00

questions.question_html:
Write a algebra expression for how much

a) How much does Elizabeth and Dragan make in total for t tables served.

b) How much does Elizabeth and Dragan make in total for 5 tables served.

\displaystyle \begin{array}{|l|l|l|} \hline & Elizabeth & Dragan \\ \hline \text{Average Weekly Tips} & \$ 220 / table & \$ 160 / table \\ \hline \text{Room and Board} & \$ 160 / week & \$ 125 / week \\ \hline \end{array}
questions.question:
Write a algebra expression for how much 

a) How much does Elizabeth and Dragan make in total for t tables served.


b) How much does Elizabeth and Dragan make in total for 5 tables served.



`$\displaystyle
\begin{array}{|l|l|l|}
\hline & Elizabeth & Dragan \\
\hline \text{Average Weekly Tips} &  \$ 220 /  table &  \$ 160 /  table \\
\hline \text{Room and Board} &  \$ 160 /  week &  \$ 125 /  week \\
\hline
\end{array}
$`
questions.answer_html:
\displaystyle \begin{aligned} T & =E+D \\ & =220 t-160+160 t-125 \\ & =220 t+160 t-160-125 \\ & =380 t-285\end{aligned}

b) \$1615

Students can choose from two different cafeteria milk plans.

b) Determine the cost of 20 glasses for each plan.

c) Determine the cost of 30 glasses for each plan.

d) Which plan would you choose? Why?

e) Identify each plan as a direct or a partial variation.

f) How does the type of variation affect the cost?
questions.question:
Students can choose from two different cafeteria milk plans. 

**Plan A**: Pay `$\$0.75$` per glass of milk

**Plan B**: Pay `$\$10$`, plus `$\$0.25$` per glass of milk

**a)** Write an equation for each plan.

**b)** Determine the cost of 20 glasses for each plan.

**c)** Determine the cost of 30 glasses for each plan.

**d)** Which plan would you choose? Why?

**e)** Identify each plan as a direct or a partial variation.

**f)** How does the type of variation affect the cost?
questions.answer:
**a)** Plan A:C=0.75g ; plan B:C=0.25g+10.00

**b)** Plan A, $15; Plan B, $15

**c)** Plan A, $22.5; Plan B, $17.5  

**d)** For less than 20 glasses of milk choose Plan A, for more than glasses choose Plan B, and for 20 glasses choose either.

**e)** Plan A is a direct variation, Plan B is a partial variation 

**f)** For example, in a partial variation there is a flat cost and a glass, so you have to pay even if you do not buy any milk. direct variation, there is no flat cost.
questions.answer_html:
a) Plan A:C=0.75g ; plan B:C=0.25g+10.00

b) Plan A, $15; Plan B, $15

c) Plan A, $22.5; Plan B, $17.5

d) For less than 20 glasses of milk choose Plan A, for more than glasses choose Plan B, and for 20 glasses choose either.

e) Plan A is a direct variation, Plan B is a partial variation

f) For example, in a partial variation there is a flat cost and a glass, so you have to pay even if you do not buy any milk. direct variation, there is no flat cost.

questions.question_html:
The amount of money in Alexander’s account is y = 4000 -70x, where y is the amount in dollars and x is the time in weeks.

b) How do you know the relation is linear?

c) Determine the rate of change of the money in Alexander’s account.

d) What does the rate of change mean?

e) How does the rate of change relate to the equation?

questions.question:
The amount of money in Alexander’s account is `$y = 4000 -70x$`, where `$y$` is the amount in dollars and x is the time in weeks.

**a)** Which variable is independent and which is dependent?

**b)** How do you know the relation is linear?

**c)** Determine the rate of change of the money in Alexander’s account.

**d)** What does the rate of change mean?

**e)** How does the rate of change relate to the equation? 

**f)** When will Alexander’s account be empty?
questions.answer:
**a)**  x, the number of weeks is independent; y, the amount of money in account is dependent. 

**b)** Answers may vary 

**c)** -$70/week

**d)** the amount of money taken out of account each week 

**e)** It is the same as the number in front of the x term the slope.

**f)** 58 weeks
questions.answer_html:
a) x, the number of weeks is independent; y, the amount of money in account is dependent.

b) Answers may vary

c) -$70/week

d) the amount of money taken out of account each week

e) It is the same as the number in front of the x term the slope.

f) 58 weeks

questions.question_html:
Amir earns $9/h working in a coffee shop and $11.25/h working in a grocery store. Last week he earned $288.

a) Explain why 9x + 11.25y = 288 models this case.

b) Is this relation a straight line? Explain.

c) Determine the x- and y-intercepts. What do they mean?

d) For how many hours might Amir have worked in each place?
questions.question:
Amir earns $9/h working in a coffee shop and $11.25/h working in a grocery store. Last week he earned $288.

**a)** Explain why `$9x + 11.25y = 288$` models this case.

**b)** Is this relation a straight line? Explain.

**c)** Determine the x- and y-intercepts. What do they mean?

**d)** For how many hours might Amir have worked in each place?
questions.answer:
**a)**  x is the hours worked at the coffee shop and y is the hours worked at the grocery store. They multiply by their  respective wages and add to give his total earnings, $288. 


**b)**  Yes, equation is of degree 1


**c)** 32; 25.6; They are the maximum amount of hours he could have worked at either job. 


**d)** Answers may vary
questions.answer_html:
a) x is the hours worked at the coffee shop and y is the hours worked at the grocery store. They multiply by their respective wages and add to give his total earnings, $288.

b) Yes, equation is of degree 1

c) 32; 25.6; They are the maximum amount of hours he could have worked at either job.

d) Answers may vary

questions.question_html:
A boat travels down the St. Lawrence River at 30 km/h and moors at a spot where the passengers can watch whales. After a while, it travels back up the river to its starting point at 20 km/h. The boat travels 60 km in all.

a) Explain why 30x + 20y = 60 models this problem. Explain what x and y represent.

b) Determine the x- and y-intercepts. What do they mean?

c) Graph the relation.
questions.question:
A boat travels down the St. Lawrence River at 30 km/h and moors at a spot where the passengers can watch whales. After a while, it travels  back up the river to its starting point at 20 km/h. The boat travels 60 km in all.

**a)** Explain why `$30x + 20y = 60$` models this problem. Explain what
`$x$` and `$y$` represent.

**b)** Determine the `$x$`- and `$y$`-intercepts. What do they mean?

**c)** Graph the relation.

questions.question_html:
George is going 6km on foot. He can run at 4km/h and walk at 2km/h.

a. Explain why 4x + 2y = 6 models the distance he will travel. What do x and y represent?

b. How long would it take him to run all the way and to walk all the way?

c. Graph the combinations of times that he could walk and run.

d. Determine three combinations of times that George could walk and run.
questions.question:
George is going 6km on foot.  He can run at 4km/h and walk at 2km/h.

a.  Explain why `$4x + 2y = 6$` models the distance he will travel.  What do `$x$` and `$y$` represent?

b. How long would it take him to run all the way and to walk all
the way?

c. Graph the combinations of times that he could walk and run.

d. Determine three combinations of times that George could walk
and run.
questions.answer:
a) `$x$` is the time spent running and `$y$` is the time spent walking. This makes sense because they multiply by their respective speeds and add to to give the total distance traveled, `$6$` km.

b) `$1.5$` h, `$3$` h

c) #3368

d) Answers may vary  (see video)

e.g., `$x=1$` and `$y=1$`, or `$x=0.5$`, and `$y=2$`, or `$x=0.25$`, and `$y=2.5$`.
questions.answer_html:

questions.question:

\hline 5 &  91.80  \\

questions.question_html:
Given each solved equation below, explain the mathematical reasoning for each step.

\displaystyle \begin{array}{cccccccc} & \frac{1}{2}x + \frac{2}{3} &= &5 \\ &6\times(\frac{1}{2}x + \frac{2}{3}) &= &5\times 6 \\ &3x + 4 &= &30 \\ &3x + 4-4 &= &30-4 \\ &3x &= &26 \\ &\frac{3x}{3} &= &\frac{26}{3} \\ &x &= &8\frac{2}{3} \\ \end{array}
questions.question:
Given each solved equation below, explain the mathematical reasoning for each step.

`$
\displaystyle
\begin{array}{cccccccc}
& \frac{1}{2}x + \frac{2}{3} &= &5 \\
&6\times(\frac{1}{2}x + \frac{2}{3}) &= &5\times 6 \\
&3x + 4 &= &30 \\
&3x + 4-4 &= &30-4  \\
&3x &= &26 \\
&\frac{3x}{3} &= &\frac{26}{3} \\
&x &= &8\frac{2}{3} \\
\end{array}
$`

questions.question_html:
A candy store is making a mixture of chocolate-coated almonds and n chocolate—coated raisins. The almonds cost $30/kg and the raisins cost $8/kg. The total cost of the mixture is to be $150.

a. Write a linear relation expressing the total cost in terms of the mass of almonds and the mass of raisins purchased.

b. Write an equation to express the mass of almonds in terms of the mass of raisins.

c. Write an equation to express the mass of raisins in terms of the mass of almonds.

d. Which combinations of almonds and raisins will cost exactly $150?
questions.question:
A candy store is making a mixture of chocolate-coated almonds and `$n$` chocolate—coated raisins. The almonds cost $30/kg and the raisins cost $8/kg. The total cost of the mixture is to be $150.

a. Write a linear relation expressing the total cost in terms of the mass of almonds and the mass of raisins purchased.

b. Write an equation to express the mass of almonds in terms of the mass of raisins.

c. Write an equation to express the mass of raisins in terms of the mass of almonds.

d. Which combinations of almonds and raisins will cost exactly $150?
questions.answer:
**(a)** `$30a+8r=150$` 


**(b)** `$1 kg$` of almonds and `$15 kg$` of raisins
questions.answer_html:
(a) 30a+8r=150

(b) 1 kg of almonds and 15 kg of raisins

questions.question_html:
Bill wants to earn extra money selling lemonade in front of his house. It costs \$1.20 to start his business and each glass of lemonade costs \$0.06 to make. He plans to sell the lemonade for \$0.10 a glass.

(a) Write an equation that represents his cost.

(b) Write an equation that represents his revenue.

(c) Graph both equations on the same set of axes.

(d) What does the point of intersection mean in this case?

(e) Does Bill make a profit or lose money for:

  • i) 20 glasses sold?
  • ii) 35 glasses sold?
  • iii) 50 glasses sold?
questions.question:
Bill wants to earn extra money selling lemonade in front of his house. It costs `$\$1.20$` to start his business and each glass of lemonade costs `$\$0.06$` to make. He plans to sell the lemonade for `$\$0.10$` a glass.


**(a)** Write an equation that represents his cost. 

**(b)** Write an equation that represents his revenue. 

**(c)** Graph both equations on the same set of axes. 

**(d)** What does the point of intersection mean in this case?

**(e)** Does Bill make a profit or lose money for:

* *i)* 20 glasses sold?
* *ii)* 35 glasses sold?
* *iii)* 50 glasses sold?
questions.answer:
**(a)** `$y=1.20+0.06x$`

**(b)** `$y=0.10x$`

**(c)** see video

**(d)** the break even point

**(e)** i) loss
ii) profit
iii) profit
questions.answer_html:
(a) y=1.20+0.06x

(b) y=0.10x

(c) see video

(d) the break even point

(e) i) loss ii) profit iii) profit

Fitness centre A has a monthly membership fee of \$90. Members pay $5 to take an aerobics class. At Fitness centre B, there is no membership fee, but clients pay \$10 per class.

a) Write a linear relation for the yearly cost in terms of the number of aerobics classes.

b) Graph the equations on the same set of axes.

c) State the point of intersection.

d) What does the point of intersection mean in this case?

e) How would you advise someone who is trying to choose between the two fitness clubs?
questions.question:
Fitness centre A has a monthly membership fee of `$\$90$`.  Members pay $5 to take an aerobics class.  At Fitness centre B, there is no membership fee, but clients pay `$\$10$` per class.

a) Write a linear relation for the yearly cost in terms of the number of aerobics classes.

b) Graph the equations on the same set of axes.

c) State the point of intersection.

d) What does the point of intersection mean in this case?

e) How would you advise someone who is trying to choose between the two fitness clubs?
questions.answer:
a) `$y=90+5x; y=10x$`

b) #3379

c) The point of intersection is `$(18,180)$`.

d) The cost for `$18$` classes is `$\$180$` regardless of which gym you join.

e) If you are going to take more than `$18$` classes a month, you should choose Faster Fitness. Any less and Drop-in Fitness is cheaper.
questions.answer_html:
a) y=90+5x; y=10x

b)

c) The point of intersection is (18,180).

d) The cost for 18 classes is \$180 regardless of which gym you join.

e) If you are going to take more than 18 classes a month, you should choose Faster Fitness. Any less and Drop-in Fitness is cheaper.

questions.question_html:
The Video Stream you can watch movies for \$ 3.00/month each and has no membership fee. At Rent Stream you can view movies for \$2/month but has a \$15 membership fee.

a) Write an equation for each situation.

b) Graph both equations on the same set of axes. Find the point of intersection.

c) What does the point of intersection mean in this case?

d) What advice would you give to someone who is deciding which video store to use?
questions.question:
The Video Stream you can watch movies for `$\$ 3.00/month$` each and has no membership fee.   At Rent Stream you can view movies for `$\$2/month$` but has a `$\$15$` membership fee.

a) Write an equation for  each situation. 

b) Graph both equations on the same set of axes.  Find the point of intersection.

c) What does the point of intersection mean in this case?

d) What advice would you give to someone who is deciding which video store to use?
questions.answer:
a) Video Vault: `$C=3v$`

Videorenters: `$C=15+2v$`

b) `$(15,45)$`

c) In this case, the point of intersection represents the number of
DVDs that have to be rented (`$15$`) to yield the same price (`$\$45$`) at
both video stores.

d) if a customer is going to rent more than 15 DVDs in a year, then
the customer should use Videorenters. If the customer is going to
rent less than 15 DVDs in a year, then the customer should use
Video Vault.
questions.answer_html:
a) Video Vault: C=3v

Videorenters: C=15+2v

b) (15,45)

c) In this case, the point of intersection represents the number of DVDs that have to be rented (15) to yield the same price (\$45) at both video stores.

d) if a customer is going to rent more than 15 DVDs in a year, then the customer should use Videorenters. If the customer is going to rent less than 15 DVDs in a year, then the customer should use Video Vault.

questions.question: Show that `$3x - 8y + 5 =  0$` and `$y =\frac{3}{8}x + \frac{5}{8}$` represents the same line.
questions.answer: `$3x-8y+5=0$`can be solved for `$y$` and gives `$y= \dfrac{3}{8}x + \dfrac{5}{8}$`, so they must be the same line.

questions.question_html:
a) Determine the slope and y-intercept for each linear equation.

  • i) 3x + 4y - 8 = 0
  • ii) 2x + 5y - 9 = 0
  • iii) 4x - 3y = -12

b) An equation is given in the form Ax+By+C=0.

  • i) What is the slope of this line?
  • ii) What is the y-intercept of this line?
questions.question:
a) Determine the slope and y-intercept for each linear equation.

* i) 3x + 4y -  8 =  0
* ii) 2x + 5y -  9 =  0
* iii) 4x  - 3y  =  -12

b) An equation is given in the form `$Ax+By+C=0$`.

* i) What is the slope of this line?
* ii) What is the y-intercept of this line?
questions.answer:
a)

i) slope = `$\dfrac{-3}{4}$`

`$y$`-intercept = `$2$`

ii) slope = `$\dfrac{-2}{5}$`

`$y$`-intercept = `$\dfrac{9}{5}$`

iii) slope = `$\dfrac{4}{3}$`

`$y$`-intercept = `$4$`

b)

i) `$-\dfrac{A}{B}$`

ii) `$- \dfrac{C}{B}$`
questions.answer_html:
a)

i) slope = \dfrac{-3}{4}

y-intercept = 2

ii) slope = \dfrac{-2}{5}

y-intercept = \dfrac{9}{5}

iii) slope = \dfrac{4}{3}

y-intercept = 4

b)

i) -\dfrac{A}{B}

ii) - \dfrac{C}{B}

questions.question_html:
Evan spend a total of $18 on gourmet jellybeans and chocolate-covered almonds. The jellybeans cost $12/kg. The almonds cost $21/kg.

(a) Write an equation to represent Evan's purchases.

(b) Isolate the variable for the quantity of jellybeans in your equation.

(c) If Evan bought 250 g of almonds, how many grams of jellybeans did he buy?

(d) If Evan bought 100g of almonds, how many grams of jellybeans did he buy?
questions.question:
Evan spend a total of $18 on gourmet jellybeans and chocolate-covered almonds.   The jellybeans cost $12/kg.   The almonds cost $21/kg.

(a) Write an equation to represent Evan's purchases.

(b) Isolate the variable for the quantity of jellybeans in your equation.

(c) If Evan bought 250 g of almonds, how many grams of jellybeans did he buy?

(d) If Evan bought 100g of almonds, how many grams of jellybeans did he buy?
questions.answer:
a. `$12x + 21y = 18$` when `$x$` is the amount of jellybeans and `$y$` is the amount of almonds.

b. `$
\displaystyle
x = -\frac{7}{4}y + \frac{3}{2}
$`

c. 1062.5 g

d. 1325 g
questions.answer_html:
a. 12x + 21y = 18 when x is the amount of jellybeans and y is the amount of almonds.

b. \displaystyle x = -\frac{7}{4}y + \frac{3}{2}

c. 1062.5 g

d. 1325 g

where `$x$` is number of loonies and `$y$` is the number of toonies.

b. #5135

c. `$(23, 18)$`

questions.question_html: How can you tell from the coordinate of two points if the line passing through them is horizontal, vertical, or slanted?
questions.question: How can you tell from the coordinate of two points if the line passing through them is horizontal, vertical, or slanted?
questions.answer:
If the `$x$`—coordinates are the same. the line is vertical. If the `$y$`—coordinates
are the same, the line is horizontal. If no coordinates are the same, the
line is slanted.
questions.answer_html: If the x—coordinates are the same. the line is vertical. If the y—coordinates are the same, the line is horizontal. If no coordinates are the same, the line is slanted.

questions.question:

questions.question_html:
Suppose each equation set represents ski hill.

a) Which two equation could not possibly represent ski hills? Why?

b) Organize the hills to: Bunny Hills(least steep), Intermediate Hills(moderately steep), and Double Black Diamond Hills(steepest).

Set 1

  1. y = x
  2. y = 7
  3. x = 2

Set 2

  1. y = \frac{2}{3}x - 7
  2. y = 2.5x - 3.7
  3. y = \frac{9}{2}x + 4

Set 3

  1. y = -\frac{1}{5}x + 8
  2. y = -6x - \frac{5}{8}
  3. y = -2x + 4
questions.question:
Suppose each equation set represents ski hill.

a) Which two equation could not possibly represent ski hills?  Why?

b) Organize the hills to: *Bunny Hills(least steep), Intermediate Hills(moderately steep), and Double Black Diamond Hills(steepest)*.

**Set 1**

1. `$y = x$`
2. `$y = 7$`
3. `$x = 2$`

**Set 2**

1. `$y = \frac{2}{3}x - 7$`
2. `$y = 2.5x - 3.7$`
3. `$y = \frac{9}{2}x + 4$`

**Set 3**

1. `$y = -\frac{1}{5}x + 8$`
2. `$y = -6x - \frac{5}{8}$`
3. `$y = -2x + 4$`
questions.answer:
a) `$y=7$` is horizontal, which is flat; `$x=2$` is vertical which represents a cliff.

Bunny Hills

`$y=\dfrac{2}{3}x-7$`

`$y=-\dfrac{1}{5}x+8$`

Intermediate Hills

`$y=x$`

Double Black Diamond Hills

`$y=-2x+4$`

`$y=2.5x-3.7$`

`$y=\dfrac{9}{2}x+4$`

`$y=-6x-\dfrac{5}{8}$`
questions.answer_html:
a) y=7 is horizontal, which is flat; x=2 is vertical which represents a cliff.

Bunny Hills

y=\dfrac{2}{3}x-7

y=-\dfrac{1}{5}x+8

Intermediate Hills

y=x

Double Black Diamond Hills

y=-2x+4

y=2.5x-3.7

y=\dfrac{9}{2}x+4

y=-6x-\dfrac{5}{8}

questions.question_html:
Movie tickets are \$8 each and concert tickets are \$12 each. Andrew spent a total of \$100 on movie and concert tickets.

a. Write an equation to represent the total cost for movie and concert tickets.

b. Rewrite the equation in the form y =mx + b

c. Determine which of the following is a possible combinations of movie and concert tickets that Andrew might have bought.
questions.question:
Movie tickets are `$\$8$` each and concert tickets are `$\$12$` each.    Andrew spent a total of `$\$100$` on movie and concert tickets.   

a.  Write an equation to represent the total cost for movie and concert tickets.   

b. Rewrite the equation in the form `$y =mx + b$`



c. Determine which of the following is a possible combinations of movie and concert tickets that Andrew might have bought.
questions.answer:
a) `$8x+12y=100$`, where `$x$` is the number of movie tickets and `$y$` is the number of concert tickets.

b) 
`$y=-\dfrac{2}{3}x+\dfrac{25}{3}$`



d) `$(movies, concert) = (2, 7) or (8, 3)$`
questions.answer_html:
a) 8x+12y=100, where x is the number of movie tickets and y is the number of concert tickets.

b) y=-\dfrac{2}{3}x+\dfrac{25}{3}

d) (movies, concert) = (2, 7) or (8, 3)

questions.question_html:
The LeBlanc family is driving home. The LeBlance are using cruise control so their speed is constant. After 3h, they are 350 km from home. After 5h, they are 130 km from home.

a) Write an equation to represent this distance-time relationship.

b) What do the slope and y-intercept of your equation mean in this situation?
questions.question:
The LeBlanc family is driving home.   The LeBlance are using cruise control so their speed is constant.  After 3h, they are 350 km from home.    After 5h, they are 130 km from home.

a) Write an equation to represent this distance-time relationship.

b) What do the slope and y-intercept of your equation mean in this situation?
questions.answer:
a) `$y=-110x+680$`, where `$x$` is the time in hours and `$y$` is the distance from home in kilometers.

b) The slope of `$-110$` means that the distance is decreasing at a rate of `$110$`km/h. The `$y$`-intercept of `$680$` means they began their trip `$680$` km away from home.
questions.answer_html:
a) y=-110x+680, where x is the time in hours and y is the distance from home in kilometers.

b) The slope of -110 means that the distance is decreasing at a rate of 110km/h. The y-intercept of 680 means they began their trip 680 km away from home.

lectures.name: 001. Modelling Cost with Fixed and Variable cost with slope intercept form

questions.question_html:
The local fall fair charges a flat fee for admission plus an additional cost for ride tickets. Last year, Kelsey purchased 15 tickets and spent a total of \$19.50. His brother Quinn purchased 36 tickets and spent a total of \$30.00 at the fair.

a) Determine an equation to represent the relationship between the total amount of money spent and the number of tickets purchased.

b) A ride pass, which gives a person entrance to the part and unlimited use of the rides, cost \$21. Write the equation for the relationship between the total amount spent on a ride pass and the number of rides it can be used for.

c) Last year, Erin used 25 tickets at the fall fair. Should Erin purchase tickets again this year, or buy a ride pass? Explain.

d) Heather only likes the fun house, which requires one ticket. She went on this ride 10 times last year. How much money would Heather save by purchasing tickets instead of a ride pass?
questions.question:
The local fall fair charges a flat fee for admission plus an additional cost for ride tickets.   Last year, Kelsey purchased 15 tickets and spent a total of `$\$19.50$`.   His brother Quinn purchased 36 tickets and spent a total of `$\$30.00$` at the fair.

a) Determine an equation to represent the relationship between the total amount of money spent and the number of tickets purchased.

b) A ride pass, which gives a person entrance to the part and unlimited use of the rides, cost `$\$21$`.  Write the equation for the relationship between the total amount spent on a ride pass and the number of rides it can be used for.

c) Last year, Erin used `$25$` tickets at the fall fair.  Should Erin purchase tickets again this year, or buy a ride pass?  Explain.

d) Heather only likes the fun house, which requires one ticket.   She went on this ride 10 times last year.   How much money would Heather save by purchasing tickets instead of a ride pass?
questions.answer:
a) `$C=0.50t+12$`, where `$C$` is the total cost, in dollars, and the `$t$` is the number of ride tickets purchased.

b) `$C=21$`, where `$C$` is the total cost, in dollars.

c) Answers may vary (see video).

e.g., since `$25$` tickets cost `$\$24.50$`, she should buy the ride pass.

d) `$\$4$`
questions.answer_html:
a) C=0.50t+12, where C is the total cost, in dollars, and the t is the number of ride tickets purchased.

b) C=21, where C is the total cost, in dollars.

c) Answers may vary (see video).

e.g., since 25 tickets cost \$24.50, she should buy the ride pass.

d) \$4

Lisa downloads music from the Music G site, which charges monthly membership fee plus an amount for each song downloaded. A three-month record of her activity on the site is shown.

\displaystyle \begin{array}{|c|c|c|} \hline Month & Number of Songs Downloaded & Monthly Bill (\$) \\ \hline January & 54 & 26.90 \\ \hline February & 38 & 25.30 \\ \hline March & 21 & 23.60 \\ \hline \end{array}

(a) Use two points from the table to determine the equation of the relationship between number of downloads and her monthly bill.

(b) Lisa's brother thinks she should change to Web W, which doesn't have a membership fee and charges \$0.95 per song. If Lisa download more than \$25/month, she should switch the plan to Web W?
questions.question:
Lisa downloads music from the Music G site, which charges monthly membership fee plus an amount for each song downloaded.   A three-month record of her activity on the site is shown.

`$\displaystyle
\begin{array}{|c|c|c|}
\hline Month & Number of Songs Downloaded & Monthly Bill (\$) \\
\hline January & 54 &  26.90  \\
\hline February & 38 &  25.30  \\
\hline March & 21 &  23.60  \\
\hline
\end{array}
$`

(a) Use two points from the table to determine the equation of the relationship between number of downloads and her monthly bill.  



(b) Lisa's brother thinks she should change to Web W, which doesn't have a membership fee and charges `$\$0.95$` per song.  If Lisa download more than `$\$25$`/month, she should switch the plan to Web W?
questions.answer:
a) `$B=0.1d+21.50$`, where `$B$` is the total bill and `$d$` is the number of songs downloaded. 

b) she should not change companies.
questions.answer_html:
a) B=0.1d+21.50, where B is the total bill and d is the number of songs downloaded.

b) she should not change companies.

lectures.name: 001. Quick Intro to Point Slope form of a Line

questions.question_html:
Given any two points on a line, the equation of the line can be determined from the point-slope form of the equation of the line:

y=m(x - p) + q
questions.question:
Given any two points on a line, the equation of the line can be determined from the point-slope form of the equation of the line: 

`$y=m(x - p) + q$`

#1685
questions.answer:
a) Substitute the coordinates into the slope formula `$\dfrac{y-q}{x-p}=m$` then isolate `$y$`.

b) `$y=3(x-1)+2$`, which simplifies to `$y=3x-1$`

c) `$y=3x-1$`

d) i) `$y=5(x-4)-6$` or `$y=5(x-5)-1$`; both simplify to `$y=5x-26$`

ii) `$y=\dfrac{2}{3}(x-3)-1$` or `$y=\dfrac{2}{3}(x-9)+3$`; both simplify to `$y=\dfrac{2}{3}x-3$`

iii) `$y=-4(x-4)+5$` or `$y=-4(x-3)+9$`; both simplify to `$y=-4x+21$`
questions.answer_html:
a) Substitute the coordinates into the slope formula \dfrac{y-q}{x-p}=m then isolate y.

b) y=3(x-1)+2, which simplifies to y=3x-1

c) y=3x-1

d) i) y=5(x-4)-6 or y=5(x-5)-1; both simplify to y=5x-26

ii) y=\dfrac{2}{3}(x-3)-1 or y=\dfrac{2}{3}(x-9)+3; both simplify to y=\dfrac{2}{3}x-3

iii) y=-4(x-4)+5 or y=-4(x-3)+9; both simplify to y=-4x+21

questions.answer:
`$m_{AB}=- \displaystyle \frac{4}{7}$` `$m_{AC} = \dfrac{7}{4}$` `$m_{CD} = -\dfrac{4}{7}$` `$m_{DB} = \dfrac{7}{4}$`

`$AB$` is perpendicular to `$AC$` and to `$DB$`.

`$CD$` is perpendicular to `$AC$` and to `$DB$`.

The quadrilateral `$ABDC$` has four right angles, so it must be a rectangle.
questions.answer_html:
m_{AB}=- \displaystyle \frac{4}{7} m_{AC} = \dfrac{7}{4} m_{CD} = -\dfrac{4}{7} m_{DB} = \dfrac{7}{4}

AB is perpendicular to AC and to DB.

CD is perpendicular to AC and to DB.

The quadrilateral ABDC has four right angles, so it must be a rectangle.

questions.question_html:
Evan and Sara shovel driveway in the winter time to earn some money. They charge $10 for a double driveway and $5 for a single driveway. This past winter, Min earned $255 and Steve earned $230.

a. Write equations for both Evan and Sarah to represent the relationship between the amounts earned shovelling single and double driveways.

b. Isolate the variable used for single driveways in both equations.

c. If they both shovelled 10 double driveways, how many single driveways did each shovel?
questions.question:
Evan and Sara shovel driveway in the winter time to earn some money. They charge $10 for a double driveway and $5 for a single driveway. This past winter, Min earned $255 and Steve earned $230.

a. Write equations for both Evan and Sarah to represent the relationship between the
amounts earned shovelling single and double driveways.

b. Isolate the variable used for single driveways in both equations.

c. If they both shovelled 10 double driveways, how many single driveways did each shovel?
questions.answer:
a) Evan: `$10d+5s=255$`; Sara: `$10d+5s=230$`, where `$d$` is the number do double driveways and `$s$` is the number of single driveways.

b) Evan: `$s=-2d+51$`; Sara: `$s=-2d+46$`

c) Evan: `$31$`; Sara: `$26$`
questions.answer_html:
a) Evan: 10d+5s=255; Sara: 10d+5s=230, where d is the number do double driveways and s is the number of single driveways.

b) Evan: s=-2d+51; Sara: s=-2d+46

c) Evan: 31; Sara: 26

a) Over what interval of time is the ATV travelling the slowest? the fastest?

b) When does the ATV start to return to its starting point? When does it get there?

c) Determine the slope of the graph between 20 s and 26 s.

d) What does a zero slope mean in the context of this graph?
questions.question:
This graph shows how an all terrain vehicle (ATV) travels over time.

a) Over what interval of time is the ATV travelling the slowest? the fastest?

b) When does the ATV start to return to its starting point?  When does it get there?

c) Determine the slope of the graph between 20 s and 26 s.

d) What does a zero slope mean in the context of this graph?

#3022
questions.answer:
a) The ATV is stopped from `$20s-26s$`. Its slowest speed while actually
moving is from `$8s-16s$`. Its fastest speed is from `$26s-32s$`.

b) The ATV begins to return to its starting point at the `$26$`s mark, and reaches its starting point at the `$32$`s mark.

c) The slope of the graph between `$20$`s and `$26$`s is `$0$`m/s.

d) A zero slope (`$0$`m/s) means that the object is not moving during a particular time interval.
questions.answer_html:
a) The ATV is stopped from 20s-26s. Its slowest speed while actually moving is from 8s-16s. Its fastest speed is from 26s-32s.

b) The ATV begins to return to its starting point at the 26s mark, and reaches its starting point at the 32s mark.

c) The slope of the graph between 20s and 26s is 0m/s.

d) A zero slope (0m/s) means that the object is not moving during a particular time interval.

A race car travels around a race track. The graph of speed vs. time for the first lap by the car is shown. a) What do the increasing parts of the graph represent? the decreasing parts?

questions.question:
A race car travels around a race track. The graph of speed vs. time for the first lap by the car is shown.
a) What do the increasing parts of the graph represent? the decreasing parts?

b) What do the horizontal parts of the graph represent?

c) Using the graph, tell a story about the car as it makes its first lap around the track.

#3032
questions.answer:
a) The increasing parts represent the time intervals when the race car is accelerating. 

The decreasing parts represent time intervals when the race car is decelerating. 

b) The horizontal parts of the graph represent time intervals when the
race car is at a constant speed.

c) Answers may vary (see video)

e.g.,  the car starts from rest and accelerates until
it approaches the first corner, then it decelerates as it travels
through this corner. As it leaves the corner, it accelerates then
decelerates as it travels through the second corner. It accelerates
again and teaches a constant speed before it decelerates through the
final corner.
questions.answer_html:
a) The increasing parts represent the time intervals when the race car is accelerating.

The decreasing parts represent time intervals when the race car is decelerating.

b) The horizontal parts of the graph represent time intervals when the race car is at a constant speed.

c) Answers may vary (see video)

e.g., the car starts from rest and accelerates until it approaches the first corner, then it decelerates as it travels through this corner. As it leaves the corner, it accelerates then decelerates as it travels through the second corner. It accelerates again and teaches a constant speed before it decelerates through the final corner.

questions.question_html: A hotel courtesy bus takes David from the airport to his hotel. Use the Distance versus Time graph to create a story that traces the route of the bus.
questions.question:
A hotel courtesy bus takes David from the airport to his hotel. Use the Distance versus Time graph to create a story that traces the route of the bus.

#2751
questions.answer: It took the bus `$22$` minutes to get to David's hotel from the airport . The bus traveled for `$1$` minute then made a stop for over a minute to probably pick up passengers at a different pickup location. It traveled for about `$2$` minutes before it made another pickup. It traveled for over `$4$` minutes and stopped again. At this stop the bus was at its furthest distance from the airport. The bus then started to travel back toward the airport for `$6$` minutes and made one final `$2$` minute stop. The bus then traveled at its greatest speed for `$2$` minutes before stopping at David's hotel.
questions.answer_html: It took the bus 22 minutes to get to David's hotel from the airport . The bus traveled for 1 minute then made a stop for over a minute to probably pick up passengers at a different pickup location. It traveled for about 2 minutes before it made another pickup. It traveled for over 4 minutes and stopped again. At this stop the bus was at its furthest distance from the airport. The bus then started to travel back toward the airport for 6 minutes and made one final 2 minute stop. The bus then traveled at its greatest speed for 2 minutes before stopping at David's hotel.

questions.question_html:
Grant leads a team of high school students who speak to elementary school students about the health problems that result from smoking cigarettes. Each high school student is responsible for one elementary school. Data on the number of hours spent by each high school student (in a year) and the corresponding number of smokers in each elementary school are summarized in the table.

\displaystyle \begin{array}{|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|} \hline Speaking Time (h) & 24 & 31 & 40 & 41 & 50 & 29 & 38 & 62 & 47 \\ \hline Number of Smokers & 36 & 27 & 16 & 10 & 3 & 23 & 20 & 1 & 19 \\ \hline \end{array}

a. Plot the data on a scatter plot.

b. Describe the pattern in the data.

c. Sketch a line or curve of best fit, whichever is more appropriate.

d. Can you conclude that the program of speaking to elementary school students has been effective in reducing smoking? Explain.

b. Describe what is happening between points C and D.

c. When does Shasta begin to travel toward home?

d. How long does it take her to get home?

e. How fast was she running back home?
questions.question:

questions.answer:

e) Shasta ran `$125$` m/min on her way home.
questions.answer_html:
a) between D and E

b) Shasta is resting.

c) after 10 min

d) 4 min

e) Shasta ran 125 m/min on her way home.

questions.answer:
Answers may vary (see video)

e.g., I predict it will not always have all sides equal.
A counterexample is a rectangle. All the angles are `$90$`°, but the sides
are not all equal.
questions.answer_html:
Answers may vary (see video)

e.g., I predict it will not always have all sides equal. A counterexample is a rectangle. All the angles are 90°, but the sides are not all equal.

questions.question_html: Create a conjecture to predict the number of diagonals from any one vertex of a convex polygon with n sides. Support your conjecture with examples or disprove it with a counterexample.
questions.question: Create a conjecture to predict the number of diagonals from any one vertex of a convex polygon with n sides. Support your conjecture with examples or disprove it with a counterexample.
questions.answer:
Answers may vary (see video)

e.g., I predict there are `$n - 3$` diagonals from each
vertex in an `$n$`-sided polygon. I think my conjecture is true. All my
examples support it. A triangle has `$0$` diagonals, a square has `$1$` diagonal.
a pentagon has `$2$` diagonals, and a hexagon has `$3$` diagonals.
questions.answer_html:
Answers may vary (see video)

e.g., I predict there are n - 3 diagonals from each vertex in an n-sided polygon. I think my conjecture is true. All my examples support it. A triangle has 0 diagonals, a square has 1 diagonal. a pentagon has 2 diagonals, and a hexagon has 3 diagonals.

questions.question_html: Test this conjecture: “If the midsegments of a quadrilateral form a square, then the quadrilateral is itself a square.”
questions.question: Test this conjecture: “If the midsegments of a quadrilateral form a square, then the quadrilateral is itself a square.”
questions.answer:
The conjecture is false. For a counterexample, I constructed an
isosceles trapezoid with bimedians forming a square.

#3515
questions.answer_html: The conjecture is false. For a counterexample, I constructed an isosceles trapezoid with bimedians forming a square.

questions.question_html: Test this conjecture: “The medians of a triangle always intersect at exactly one point.”
questions.question: Test this conjecture: “The medians of a triangle always intersect at exactly one point.”
questions.answer:
The conjecture is true. 

Answers may vary (see video)

e.g., I drew several triangles
using The Geometer's Sketchpad and then drew their medians. The
medians for each triangle always intersected in one point. All my
examples—an equilateral triangle, an isosceles triangle, `$3$` right
triangle, and two scalene triangles—supported the conjecture
questions.answer_html:
The conjecture is true.

Answers may vary (see video)

e.g., I drew several triangles using The Geometer's Sketchpad and then drew their medians. The medians for each triangle always intersected in one point. All my examples—an equilateral triangle, an isosceles triangle, 3 right triangle, and two scalene triangles—supported the conjecture

questions.question_html: Test this conjecture: “It is always possible to draw a circle through all four vertices in a rectangle.”
questions.question: Test this conjecture: “It is always possible to draw a circle through all four vertices in a rectangle.”
questions.answer:
The conjecture is true.

Answers may vary (see video)

e.g., I drew different
rectangles using The Geometer’s Sketchpad. Then I looked for possible
circles. The centre of the circle was always at the intersection of the
diagonals of the rectangle. I intersected the diagonals of every
rectangle and then drew a circle with a centre at the intersection
point. I always found one that intersected each vertex.
questions.answer_html:
The conjecture is true.

Answers may vary (see video)

e.g., I drew different rectangles using The Geometer’s Sketchpad. Then I looked for possible circles. The centre of the circle was always at the intersection of the diagonals of the rectangle. I intersected the diagonals of every rectangle and then drew a circle with a centre at the intersection point. I always found one that intersected each vertex.

questions.question_html: Billy claims that the sum of the interior angles of a regular octagon is 900^o. Is he correct? Justify your decision.
questions.question: Billy claims that the sum of the interior angles of a regular octagon is `$900^o$`.   Is he correct?  Justify your decision.
questions.answer:
He is incorrect.

Answers may vary (see video)

e.g., I know the sum of the interior angles of an `$n$`-gon is `$180 \times (n-2)$` degrees. This works out to `$1080^\circ$` for an octagon.
questions.answer_html:
He is incorrect.

Answers may vary (see video)

e.g., I know the sum of the interior angles of an n-gon is 180 \times (n-2) degrees. This works out to 1080^\circ for an octagon.

questions.question_html:
a) Calculate the measure of each interior angle of a regular 25- gon.

b) What is the measure of each exterior angle?
questions.question:
a) Calculate the measure of each interior angle of a regular 25-
gon.

b) What is the measure of each exterior angle?
questions.answer:
**wrong video or wrong question** 


a) `$2$` is subtracted from `$n$` to give the number of triangles that are
formed by the diagonals of the `$n$`-gon.

b) `$(n-2)$` is multiplied by `$180^\circ$`, because there are `$180^\circ$` in each of the triangles that are formed by the diagonals of the `$n$`-gon.
questions.answer_html:
wrong video or wrong question

a) 2 is subtracted from n to give the number of triangles that are formed by the diagonals of the n-gon.

b) (n-2) is multiplied by 180^\circ, because there are 180^\circ in each of the triangles that are formed by the diagonals of the n-gon.

questions.question_html:
For each right pyramid, the base is a regular polygon with a=4 cm and h=10 cm.

Find the volume in term of s.
questions.question:
For each right pyramid, the base is a regular polygon with `$a$`=4 cm and `$h$`=10 cm. 	

#2315

Find the volume in term of `$s$`.
questions.answer:
`$V = \dfrac{1}{6}nhsa$`, where `$V$` is the volume of an `$n$`-sided pyramid, `$s$` is its side length, and `$a$` is the distance from the centre of the base to the midpoint of an edge.

`$V = \dfrac{10}{3} \pi a^2$`

(see video for further solution)
questions.answer_html:
V = \dfrac{1}{6}nhsa, where V is the volume of an n-sided pyramid, s is its side length, and a is the distance from the centre of the base to the midpoint of an edge.

V = \dfrac{10}{3} \pi a^2

(see video for further solution)

Kim runs a company that makes ball bearings. The bearings are shipped in boxes that are then loaded onto trucks. Each bearing has a diameter of 0.96 cm.

a) Each box can hold 8000 cm^3 of ball bearings. How many ball bearings can a box hold?

b) Each ball bearing has a mass of 0.95 g. Determine the mass of each box.

c) The maximum mass a truck can carry is 11 000 kg. What is the maximum number of boxes that can be loaded into a truck?

d) Besides the ball bearings' mass, what else must Kim consider when loading a truck?
questions.question:
Kim runs a company that makes ball bearings. The bearings are shipped in boxes that are then loaded onto trucks. Each bearing has a diameter of 0.96 cm.


**a)** Each box can hold 8000 `$cm^3$` of ball bearings. How many ball bearings can a box hold?

**b)** Each ball bearing has a mass of 0.95 g. Determine the mass of each box. 

**c)** The maximum mass a truck can carry is 11 000 kg. What is the maximum number of boxes that can be loaded into a truck?

**d)** Besides the ball bearings' mass, what else must Kim consider when loading a truck?
questions.answer:
a) `$17269$` ball bearings

b) `$16405.55$` g

c) `$670$` boxes

d) Answers may vary (see video)

e.g., the shape, size, and mass of each box
questions.answer_html:
a) 17269 ball bearings

b) 16405.55 g

c) 670 boxes

d) Answers may vary (see video)

e.g., the shape, size, and mass of each box

a) Complete the table.

\displaystyle \begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|} \hline Shape & Surface Area \left(\mathrm{cm}^{2}\right) & Dimensions (\mathrm{cm}) & Volume \left(\mathrm{cm}^{3}\right) \\ \hline square-based prism & 1000 & s=10, h=x & \\ \hline cylinder & 1000 & r=10, h=x & \\ \hline sphere & 1000 & r \doteq x & \\ \hline \end{array}

b) Which shape has the greatest volume?
questions.question:
**a)** Complete the table.

`$\displaystyle
\begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline Shape & Surface Area  \left(\mathrm{cm}^{2}\right)  & Dimensions  (\mathrm{cm})  & Volume  \left(\mathrm{cm}^{3}\right)  \\
\hline square-based prism & 1000 &  s=10, h=x  & \\
\hline cylinder & 1000 &  r=10, h=x  & \\
\hline sphere & 1000 &  r \doteq x  & \\
\hline
\end{array}
$`

**b)** Which shape has the greatest volume?
questions.answer:
a) #3535

`$\displaystyle
\begin{array}{|l|c|l|c|}
\hline { Shape } & Surface Area  \mathbf{( c m}^{2} \mathbf{)}  & Dimensions  \mathbf{( c m )}  & Volume  \mathbf{( c m}^{\mathbf{3}} \mathbf{)}  \\
\hline squarebased prism & 1000 &  s=10  ,  h=20  & 2000 \\
\hline cylinder & 1000 &  r=10  ,  h=5.92  &  1858.88  \\
\hline sphere & 1000 &  r=9  & 2974 \\
\hline
\end{array}
$`

b) sphere
questions.answer_html:
a)

\displaystyle \begin{array}{|l|c|l|c|} \hline { Shape } & Surface Area \mathbf{( c m}^{2} \mathbf{)} & Dimensions \mathbf{( c m )} & Volume \mathbf{( c m}^{\mathbf{3}} \mathbf{)} \\ \hline squarebased prism & 1000 & s=10 , h=20 & 2000 \\ \hline cylinder & 1000 & r=10 , h=5.92 & 1858.88 \\ \hline sphere & 1000 & r=9 & 2974 \\ \hline \end{array}

b) sphere
